audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of old-school catch wrestling, particularly its throws, mentioning common discussions around groundwork and rivalry with Judo's ground techniques. He announces a focus on throws, referencing a book with the title "The Art the Science of Wrestling and the Art of Jujitsu" as the main source of information. He clarifies that he will be focusing on the wrestling part of the book.

The audio starts with a male speaker beginning to describe a technique, mentioning terms like "inside leg and arm drop." He speaks in a relatively calm tone, noting there is nothing particularly unique to discuss, citing similarities to "Katamata" and the "fireman's carry." He mentions commonality with folk-style wrestling and other disciplines, adding that even the one-knee block is present. He then mentions checking out a "Kukokan" example. The speaker describes someone pulling "Kusushi" and utilizing the one-knee position, throwing the opponent over the shoulder with the hand. He reiterates that this is not especially remarkable and can be found in many martial arts styles.

A male speaker discusses an interesting technique involving a back heel, arm wrapping, and driving backwards. He connects it to "Osoto Otoshi" or "Osoto Gari", noting that it resembles Scottish backhold wrestling and catch wrestling. He mentions that while there's a Judo approach, the entry differs and references the Pedro footage, courtesy of Fighting Films, available in the description.

The clip begins with a single male speaker describing a judo move by Kayla Harrison, detailing the specific maneuvers and differences in technique compared to a standard throw. He expresses curiosity about how a catch wrestler might approach the move. The speech includes technical language, with a clear tone. Subsequently, the speaker describes another wrestling move, noting the occurrence of a leg grab and a leg reap simultaneously.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing catch wrestling and striking disciplines, mentioning moves like "O Uchi Gari." His tone is informative. He also discusses Judo and terminology like "Soto Ashidori" and "Torimasu," citing "efficient Judo" as a source. He mentions the use of grabbing in MMA and Karate to perform techniques like "Kouchi" or "Deashiharai," or simply to pummel opponents.

A male speaker begins by mentioning "grabbing the leg" during a strike and tearing the other one, noting its commonality. He asserts that the human body is the same worldwide, making conclusions easy. His interest lies in the entry, but old books don't offer much assistance due to the time and printing limitations.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing a double leg takedown technique. His tone is analytical and slightly critical as he questions the effectiveness of certain elements of the technique. He expresses uncertainty, saying he doesn't want to be wrong, but questions the optimality of the approach. The speaker then describes the technique as a "Morote-gari", explaining that you don't have to pick up. He describes a dive in "kind of like a tackle", emphasizing the importance of going low and not bending the back like a wrestler. He ends the segment with a question regarding finishing the takedown due to its inefficiency and proneness to attacks.

A male speaker, with a focused tone, begins by explaining a move from a double wristlock grip, noting it's an "underrated grip" for takedowns and common in grappling, especially for "sumi gaeshi." He cites examples of martial artists, naming "Shoori Hamada, Uta Abe, and Masahiko Kimura." The speaker mentions plans to demonstrate examples later before transitioning to the "this one," likely referring to a specific technique.

The clip starts with a male speaker brainstorming possibilities, mentioning a "legless fireman" and techniques like "I kido's Kokyunage." His tone is enthusiastic as he suggests various moves, such as "whip it downward" and "Yoko Wakare." He then transitions to describing a specific grip and its advantages in taking someone's balance, followed by references to "Utabe" and Masahiko Kimura, describing how they use a similar technique. The male speaker notes that  "Bushart" is "just tapping endlessly." The male speaker's tone is enthusiastic and descriptive.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the efficiency of a grip technique, elaborating on its use in submissions and maintaining a pin. He speaks in an informative tone, promising to demonstrate a simple example. The speaker describes a wrestling hold called Ushiro Kesa Gatame and its effectiveness in maintaining control. He emphasizes the grip's efficiency for both submissions and takedowns.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Russian tie-ins and grip techniques, admitting uncertainty about the subject and stating that no-gi isn't his area of expertise. He then invites listeners to comment and mentions that a book link will be available in the description below. The clip features only one speaker, with a casual, conversational tone.

The audio clip features a male speaker expressing gratitude for the links, books, and material he received from friends, which he intends to discuss. He also requests support on Patreon for exclusive content. The speaker sounds thankful and concludes by saying "only this was Chatty and thank you for listening".
